awd_titl_txt: DMREF: Data Driven Discovery of Conjugated Polyelectrolytes for Neuromorphic Computing
awd_abstract_narration:
DMREF: Data Driven Discovery of Conjugated Polyelectrolytes for Neuromorphic Computing

Non-Technical Description:  
As a potentially disruptive technology, neuromorphic computing breaks away from the current performance-limiting conventional computer architectures (i.e. von Neumann paradigm) by developing biologically inspired computational devices with artificial intelligence capabilities. Organic electronic materials have recently emerged as attractive alternatives to inorganic counterparts in neuromorphic computing owing to their low-energy switching, excellent tunability, low fabrication costs, and biocompatibility. In this project, we will establish a collaborative, multidisciplinary and data-centric research program to accelerate the discovery of novel conjugated polyelectrolytes (CPEs) with chemical structures tailored for the demands of neuromorphic computing. The project will bear direct impact on applications ranging from neuromorphic computing, to energy generation (photovoltaic and thermoelectric materials), sensing, robotics, and pathogen mitigation. The project will also provide cutting-edge educational and training opportunities to students and postdoctoral fellows who will gain valuable experience in data science, materials informatics, and data driven material research. The PIs are fully committed to broadening participation and enhancing diversity in materials research and education by strengthening opportunities for underrepresented groups in STEM fields. Exposing the underrepresented groups to data centric research and education is a key component of the project. A set of courses will be developed at various levels in both participating institutions to prepare the students and postdoctoral fellows for the proposed research. The PIs will reach out to local high schools and community colleges through targeted recruitment, workshops, and summer camps for high school teachers.

Technical Description: 
The proposed research will significantly accelerate the discovery of CPE materials specifically designed for neuromorphic computing. The research effort integrates high-throughput computation, machine learning, multiscale modeling, chemical synthesis, and materials and device characterization executed in a "closed loop" manner. The team will construct the first comprehensive database dedicated to CPEs, which includes a collection of structural, elastic, vibrational, electronic, dielectric, and energetic properties for over ten thousand CPEs. Based on the CPE database, the team will explore the correlations between the materials properties and formulate a set of molecular design rules. Materials characterization will be performed to validate the design rules and once validated, they will provide guidance for predictions of promising CPEs. Based on the predictions, the team will synthesize the most promising CPEs and examine their performance in the neuromorphic devices. The project has three deliverables: (1) The first comprehensive CPE database. (2) A fundamental understanding on how the backbone structure and adjacent electrostatic forces control CPE properties and a set of design rules for accelerated materials discovery. (3) A set of highly optimized and promising CPE structures for neuromorphic and optoelectronic applications. Successful completion of the project not only impacts neuromorphic computing, but also research areas, such as photovoltaics, light-emitting diodes, thermoelectrics, sensors and robotics. The potential to affect transformative breakthroughs in the rational design of neuromorphic and organic electronic materials makes a compelling case for the project.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
Project Outcomes Report (DMR-1922042)

 

DMREF: Data Driven Discovery of Conjugated Polyelectrolytes for Neuromorphic Computing 

 

 

The overarching objective of the DMREF project is to establish a collaborative, multidisciplinary and data-centric research program which accelerates the discovery of novel conjugated polyelectrolytes (CPEs) with chemical structures tailored for the demands of neuromorphic engineering. The project integrated high-throughput computation, machine learning, multiscale modeling, materials synthesis, and device characterization in a “closed loop” fashion. 

 

Intellectual Merit: 

The project involved researchers with complementary expertise (Physics, Chemistry and Materials Science) and skills (computation, synthesis and characterization). In this project, we have developed the first CPE database https://www.cpegenome.com/ by combined first-principles high-throughput computation and machine learning modeling. The CPE database includes a collection of structural, elastic, vibrational, electronic, dielectric, and energetic properties for over 10,000 CPEs. Based on the CPE database, we explored correlations between the materials properties and structural features of CPEs. We have formulated a set of design rules for molecular structures with prescribed properties. More specifically, we have predicted a number of promising CPEs for neuromorphic and optoelectronic applications. Experimental validation of these predictions has been carried out systematically. There has also been iterative feedback between theory and experiment on the synthesis and characterization of CPEs. For example, first-principles calculations were performed to understand the experimental observations of doping level dependence on the side-chain length in CPEs. In addition, a comprehensive first-principles study on the stability, structural deformation, electronic structure, and optical absorption of positive/negative polarons and bi-polarons in CPEs was conducted. We explored how these properties depend on the electrostatic interaction between the polarons and ionic functionalities, including alkyl chains, ionic groups, and counterions. We studied how the bandgap, polaron binding energy, and optoelectronic structure of CPEs can be tuned by various combinations of the donor and acceptor units in their backbones. The strategy to improve the electrochemical stability of n-doped CPEs was also examined. Simultaneously, important progress has been made in experimental efforts. For example, a self-doped CPE-K was utilized to fabricate organic electrochemical transistors (OECTs) with high transconductance in the accumulation mode. The physical and electrical properties of CPE-K were fully characterized to allow direct comparisons to other top performing OECT materials. CPE-K demonstrates an electrical performance that is among the best reported in the literature for OECT materials. In addition, CPE-K OECTs operate in the accumulation mode, which allows for much lower energy consumption in comparison to commonly used depletion mode devices. Moreover, a new method was developed to make air-stable n-type organic mixed ionic-electronic conductor films for OECTs using a solution-processable small molecule, helical perylene diimide trimer. Alkyl side chains were attached to the conjugated core for processability and film making, which were then cleaved via thermal annealing. The materials offered improved ionic transport, greater electronic mobility, and increased stability in air and in aqueous solution. Used as the active material in OECTs, the device displays a transconductance of 44 mS, volumetric capacitance of ≈250 F cm−3, µC* value of 1 F cm−1 V−1s−1, and excellent stability (> 5 weeks). As proof of their practical applications, the OECTs are used as a glucose sensor and electrochemical inverter. The work charts a path to a wide range of molecular semiconductors to be used as stable, mixed ionic-electronic conductors.

 

Broad Impacts

Given the wide range of potential applications of CPEs, the project is expected to have broad impacts. Specifically, the proposed research will bear direct impacts on applications, ranging from neuromorphic computing to energy generation (photovoltaics, photocatalysis, thermoelectrics), sensing, robotics, and pathogen mitigation. The proposed CPE database is expected to be widely mined and used by the scientific community because the database is the only comprehensive one dedicated to CPEs. We have also developed a new first-principles method which will be made available to the research community. The work on OECTs establishes a platform to characterize CPEs based OECT performance, highlighting the potential of CPEs in OECTs and pointing toward future design of CPEs in neuromorphic applications. The broader impact of the project also arises from the cutting-edge educational and training opportunities offered by the research program. In particular, students and postdoctoral scholars have gained valuable experience in data science, materials informatics, and data driven material research. The PIs were fully committed to broadening participation in materials research and education by actively recruiting and mentoring students in the contemporary areas of science and technology. 

 

This Project Outcomes Report for the General Public is displayed verbatim as submitted by the Principal Investigator (PI) for this award. Any opinions, findings, and conclusions or recommendations expressed in this Report are those of the PI and do not necessarily reflect the views of the National Science Foundation; NSF has not approved or endorsed its content.

 


Last Modified: 01/31/2025
Modified by: Gang Lu

The overarching objective of the DMREF project is to establish a collaborative, multidisciplinary and data-centric research program which accelerates the discovery of novel conjugated polyelectrolytes (CPEs) with chemical structures tailored for the demands of neuromorphic engineering.
